title: Ford_Geely_in_talks_over_European_production__report.pdf
evidence_bullets: Ford and Geely are reportedly discussing European production for the EU market.
The talks aim to utilize Ford’s excess production capacity in Europe.
The EU imposed tariffs on Chinese-built BEVs on October 30, 2024.
Tariffs range from 7.8% (Tesla) to 35.3% for non-cooperating companies.
key_insights: OEMs like Ford and Geely are exploring new strategies to adapt to EU tariffs on Chinese BEV imports.
Ford's existing production capacity in Europe is becoming a strategic asset for collaborations.
EU tariffs are a significant driver for changes in automotive manufacturing and supply chains in Europe.
strategic_implications: Potential for new manufacturing partnerships and platforms in Europe to circumvent trade barriers.
Shifting production locations will impact regional supplier demand and competitive landscape.
The need for flexible supply chain solutions to support evolving OEM production strategies in Europe.
notes: This report highlights OEM adaptation to EU tariffs on Chinese BEVs and the strategic use of existing production capacity.

title: Ford’s aluminum supplier Novelis not yet back at full output after 2025 fire
region_signal_type: Specific location in US, impacting North America
evidence_bullets: Novelis's aluminum plant in Oswego, New York, has not fully resumed output.
A September 2025 fire initially pushed full production return to December.
A second fire in late November further delayed the recovery timeline.
Novelis is now leveraging global alternate sources to maintain supply.
key_insights: Ford's key aluminum supplier, Novelis, faces significant production delays after two plant fires.
The second fire in November further complicated recovery, making the reopening date uncertain.
Novelis is using alternate global sources to manage supply disruptions for its customers.
strategic_implications: Ford may face aluminum supply chain disruptions impacting vehicle production schedules.
This highlights the vulnerability of single-source material supply chains for OEMs.
OEMs might need to review and diversify their critical material sourcing strategies.
recommended_actions: Monitor Novelis's recovery progress and its impact on Ford's production.
Assess any potential indirect effects on Kiekert's component demand from Ford.
Review supply chain resilience strategies for critical materials.
notes: Information about Novelis, a significant aluminum supplier, facing ongoing production challenges due to multiple plant fires. This directly impacts Ford and potentially the broader automotive industry.

title: Ford to take USD 6 billion hit for disposition of BlueOval SK
evidence_bullets: Ford expects a USD 6 billion hit from dissolving its EV battery joint venture with SK On.
Ford will assume all liabilities and assets of BlueOval SK's Kentucky operations.
The BlueOval SK Battery Park plant in Kentucky will close, leading to 1,512 layoffs.
The plant was intended to produce LFP batteries for Ford Energy.
key_insights: Ford is facing significant financial repercussions from its EV battery joint venture strategy.
The closure of BlueOval SK Battery Park highlights challenges in large-scale EV battery production.
This move indicates a strategic re-evaluation of Ford's EV battery supply chain approach.
strategic_implications: OEMs face substantial risks and costs when developing in-house battery production capabilities.
Supply chain stability for critical EV components remains a volatile area for the automotive industry.
This could impact Ford's future EV production timelines and cost efficiencies.
notes: The article details the financial impact and operational changes related to Ford's EV battery production strategy, specifically the dissolution of its joint venture with SK On and the closure of a battery plant in Kentucky.

title: Western European passenger car registrations fall 2.8% in January – S&P Global Mobility forecast
key_insights: The Western European passenger car market had a slow start in January, with varied regional performances.
Regulatory changes, particularly in France, significantly impact ICE sales and boost BEV registrations.
Geopolitical tensions and supply chain issues continue to pose challenges for the automotive sector.
Chinese-owned brands are gaining significant market share, especially in the UK.
strategic_implications: Companies must closely monitor evolving European CO2 targets and government incentives for BEVs.
Diversifying supply chains and adapting to regional regulatory nuances will be crucial for market stability.
Competitors should analyze the growing influence of Chinese OEMs in key European markets.
Develop flexible product strategies to address diverse customer preferences amid powertrain shifts and economic uncertainties.
evidence_bullets: Western European passenger car registrations fell 2.7% year-over-year in January to 860,319 units.
Germany and France saw declines due to calendar effects and malus payments respectively.
Italy, Spain, and the UK reported varied January results, with BEVs growing in France and Italy.
S&P Global Mobility forecasts a 1.9% growth for Western European passenger car registrations in 2026.
